text:
Alaska Severe Storm Seasonal Risk Profile

Alaska has recorded 72 FEMA severe storm declarations from 2000–2026 (26 years of data). During active months, the state averages 2.9 declarations per month. Activity peaks in September, October, and November, with the highest-risk window being September–November.

6-Year Forecast (model CV MAE=0.14):
Our Prophet time series model projects severe storm declaration frequency in Alaska through February 2032. During forecasted peak months (September, October, November), the model predicts an average of 0.4 declarations/month. During off-season months, activity is expected to remain near 0.0 declarations/month.

Workforce Impact:
Industries most affected by severe storm declarations in Alaska include agriculture, construction, utilities, and outdoor industries. Workers and employers in Alaska should anticipate potential workforce disruption during September–November. Disaster declaration frequency is seasonal — some years may see significantly more or fewer events depending on weather patterns.

Important note: These forecasts predict FEMA declaration frequency (how often disasters are formally declared), not disaster probability or severity. A single major event can generate many county-level declarations in one month.

Alaska Flood Seasonal Risk Profile

Alaska has recorded 61 FEMA flood declarations from 2000–2026 (26 years of data). During active months, the state averages 4.5 declarations per month. Activity peaks in May, April, and October, with the highest-risk window being April–October.

6-Year Forecast (model CV MAE=1.00):
Our Prophet time series model projects flood declaration frequency in Alaska through February 2032. During forecasted peak months (May, April, October), the model predicts an average of 0.8 declarations/month. During off-season months, activity is expected to remain near 0.2 declarations/month.

Workforce Impact:
Industries most affected by flood declarations in Alaska include agriculture, real estate, retail, and manufacturing near waterways. Workers and employers in Alaska should anticipate potential workforce disruption during April–October. Disaster declaration frequency is seasonal — some years may see significantly more or fewer events depending on weather patterns.

Important note: These forecasts predict FEMA declaration frequency (how often disasters are formally declared), not disaster probability or severity. A single major event can generate many county-level declarations in one month.

Missouri has recorded 1,342 FEMA severe storm declarations from 2000–2026 (26 years of data). During active months, the state averages 34.7 declarations per month. Activity peaks in May, April, and March, with the highest-risk window being March–May.

6-Year Forecast (model CV MAE=5.12):
Our Prophet time series model projects severe storm declaration frequency in Missouri through February 2032. During forecasted peak months (May, April, March), the model predicts an average of 9.1 declarations/month. During off-season months, activity is expected to remain near 1.0 declarations/month.

Workforce Impact:
Industries most affected by severe storm declarations in Missouri include agriculture, construction, utilities, and outdoor industries. Workers and employers in Missouri should anticipate potential workforce disruption during March–May. Disaster declaration frequency is seasonal — some years may see significantly more or fewer events depending on weather patterns.

Important note: These forecasts predict FEMA declaration frequency (how often disasters are formally declared), not disaster probability or severity. A single major event can generate many county-level declarations in one month.

Texas has recorded 610 FEMA flood declarations from 2000–2026 (26 years of data). During active months, the state averages 26.7 declarations per month. Activity peaks in April, June, and May, with the highest-risk window being April–June.

Workforce Impact:
Industries most affected by flood declarations in Texas include agriculture, real estate, retail, and manufacturing near waterways.
